snippet: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said that they would support a vote by Crimeans to break away from Ukraine, ignoring sanctions threats and warnings from the U.S. and other countries.
abstract: Russia signals for first time that it is prepared to annex the Crimea region of Ukraine; move threatens to undermine a system of respect for national boundaries that has helped keep the peace in Europe and elsewhere for decades; action also intensifies confrontation with the West, ignoring threat of sanctions and argument that a vote for secession would violate Ukraine's Constitution and international law.

byline.original: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Steven Lee Myers reported from Moscow, David M. Herszenhorn from Simferopol, Ukraine, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Alan Cowell from London; Ellen Barry from Moscow; Michael R. Gordon from Shannon, Ireland; Alissa J. Rubin from Brussels; Peter Baker from Washington; Steven Erlanger from Kiev, Ukraine; Somini Sengupta from the United Nations; and Noah Sneider from Simferopol.

lead_paragraph: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said that they would support a vote by Crimeans to break away from Ukraine, ignoring sanctions threats and warnings from the U.S. and other countries.

headline.main: For First Time, Kremlin Signals It Is Prepared to Annex Crimea
headline.print_headline: Russia Prepared to Annex Crimea, Deepening Crisis
